This book is essentially thirteen chapters, each addressing a topic which science has (so far) not explained. Overall the writing style is engaging and some pretty technical subjects are kept light and accessible. The concept of examining scientific mysteries is interesting and some of the chapters have really fascinating nuggets of information. The first ten chapters are best, with some being brilliant. The last three chapters are weaker and less convincing, and it is apparent that the author is further from his comfort zone with these, but still contain some interesting reading. Overall, recommended reading for pop science fans.

I liked this book. I did not, however, love it. I think my problem is that the author equates genuine mysteries of the universe like Dark Energy or the creation of life with homeopathy... those things don't belong in the same book. The efficacy of homeopathy is well documented. It doesn't fare so well in clinical trials. But most of the 13 things mentioned are real scientific mysteries, and they are covered pretty well I think, considering how little space is devoted to each one. If you're interested in them then I'd give this a read, but again, nothing new is really being added to the conversation, well, aside from an anecdote or two I'd not heard before.

I've always had a quizzical mind when it comes to our universe and the mysteries that lurk within it. And I love books like this that help lift the cover off slightly. Although written by a scientist, "13 things that don't make sense" is written in a way that even a barbary ape could understand. Michael Brookes explores topics such as free will (something, according to scientists, we may not have), the WOW signal (a radio signal from outer space that lasted just 3 minutes) and the missing universe (only 4% of it, apparently, can be accounted for.If you like science and you like mysteries, then this book combines both. A fascinating read.

I love that the author dedicated this book to one of his physic teachers. I love knowing that there are teachers out there who inspire their students, especially in the sciences.I said this in status updates, but I quite enjoyed how well the chapters transitioned into each other. It helped to provide some structure to a book that could have been about 13 head-scratchy but not necessarily related science topics. I do wish there had been more on ethics though, especially In the chapter on death. I would recommend this to anyone who is scientifically curious, with a basic science background.
Interesting and easy to grasp concepts, but a little dry.

Some topics are a bit duller than others, but what I enjoyed was the descriptions of these scientific theories through the scientists that study them. The focus was on the history of these scientists, their squabbling or cooperation, and how the funding (or lack thereof) affected our general knowledge of these topics. An interesting take on how all scientific theory depends on those choosing to study and publish and thus the development of noble Science is just as biased and flawed as any human pursuit.

The problem with books about science is that it's really difficult to hit the point where you have enough detail to really engage the reader in the subject without going so far in that you lose them. This book, I think, lost a little on the side of fluffiness: there were too many places where I went "but what does that MEAN?"I was tempted to give it four stars, anyway, just because approximately every 10 pages or so I found myself wanting to look up from the book and turn to the person next to me and exclaim, "This is SO COOL!"

Very interesting. The book is divided into little snippets that don't have to be read in order. The author describes things in a non-technical and lively manner.I think the overall theme of how scientists suffer from "group think" and "herd behavior" was as interesting as any of the other things sceince hasn't been able to explain. We think we've advanced, but Gallileo would be just as persecuted today for his "controversial" ideas as we was hundreds of years ago. People don't change, I guess.

This book made my brain hurt. I mean, it was really good, but the science was a challenge.OK, I'll admit I was only half way done when I put this on my "Read" shelf. I finished it today and I have to say that it gets easier and easier to read. The science gets easier to follow because we move out of cold fusion and anti-matter and into the Wow! Signal, why sexual reproduction is problematic for evolution and what the placebo effect and homeopathy are and aren't.Worth pushing through to the second half of the book.

I think I more moved my eyes across the pages of this book than read it. It isn't a fault of the book, just more my state of mind during this period of time. Iwasn't paying much attention to anything in particular.Overall, I found the topics presented interesting and worthy of learning about. It wasn't too technical, though I really just glazed over the stuff I didn't understand instead of really trying to learn anything (see above). Especially the physics topics. Though I was much more interested in the chapters towards the end that were more medical in nature.

I was very disappointed in this book. Good pretense, great title... but the writing was discursive, the science flabby, the points opaque, the logic tenuous, the conclusions inconclusive.I know. The point was that these topic were not nice tight bundles with a clear coherent conclusion... after all, they don't make sense. I accept that premise. And, it could have been cool. There are just better, more interesting, better written, more scientifically sound or rigorous books. I suggest that you read them instead.My book group was unanimous in its general condemnation.

First thing I want to say is that, its not so much that I finished this book, rather than that I'm finished with it.I pretty much gave up on this book after having read the first paragraph.Once I finished the first paragraph, I skimmed it, and by the end of the first chapter I had read anywhere between 0-20 words on each page. I'm pretty surprised myself that I couldn't get into it so soon because I've been wanting to read this book for a long while now. It was boring. I was hoping that it would have been written in a more entertaining way.

Stick to physics. Homeopathy? Brooks at least ordered the mysteries from dark matter (if as yet, unexplainable) to, well, homeopathy. The continuum of possible to highly improbable is covered. Not a waste, for Brooks explains his rationale well, but he will certainly fuel and maybe even satisfy the fringe fans (think R. A. Wilson).I had a subscription to New Scientist (Brooks is the tie-in)several years ago but the issues were to frequent and I couldn't keep up. I wonder if they play with fringes now.

I really liked this! It made me want to be a scientist again, which is saying a lot. This book is definitely not for everyone. It's fairly dry and very sciency (obviously), but if you're a geek like me and like pondering the mysteries of the universe, then it's great. It got me thinking in a different way than I have been lately - a very good thing. I listened to the audiobook, and wouldn't have made it through if not for 1.5x speed. Otherwise it would have been way to slow and put me to sleep. Any faster, though, and I probably would've gotten lost.

Not very hard science but tells interesting personal narratives about some peculiar, troubling, and interesting problems facing the scientific community. While they are loosely tied together, the 13 things each have their own story and it's implied that its solution will require a paradigm shift to accommodate one way or the other. I wouldn't take everything at face value and I'm sure progress has been made since the publication of this book, but it's an interesting take on science and the nature of scientific revolution and accessible to non-scientists.

This is a good read. The book is well written and full of science facts about “stuff” that doesn’t make sense. It is a book to inform and allow your mind to theorize and reflect. The topics are all explained in a simple and understandable way and includes death, sex, life, dark matter, free will, alien hand syndrome, and the placebo effect. Brooks has done his research well, producing a thought provoking and interesting read which will provide challenging topics of conversation in your social circles.

I really liked this overview of mysteries in physics and medicine. Particularly interesting was an overview of The Pioneer anomaly along with research on the placebo effect, counterexamples to the certainty of death (such as Blanding's_turtle), and homoeopathy. I particularly appreciated the author's exploration of placebos and homoeopaths with arguments for and against, such as the weak foundation of a meta-analysis of placebo studies.,

There are some amazing possibilities just beyond the horizon of our current scientific knowledge. Some of these mysteries are widely publicized as mysteries: Dark Matter, Dark Energy, Cold Fusion, the mystery of Life. But many are scientific black sheep, tucked away in a corner. Like what is the evolutionary purpose of death and sexual reproduction. Also, free will appears to be a construct that your brain produces as a side effect of it's activities. This was a very well written review of these mysteries. I wonder how science will look back on these mysteries in the future.

It started out at a fascinating book talking about a lot of mysteries in physics and gave the historical background to them. Then each topic got less and less interesting. Maybe it is because I have a physics degree and appreciate those topics more. It even spoke of cold fusion which I was a part of back in school. I’m glad I read the book and I’m probably being a little harsh only giving it 3 stars but there are so many better books out there.

Fantastic overall. He strangely doesn't talk about how quantum mechanics and relativity theories aren't unified at this point - the biggest and most embarrassing problem in physics. A few things that don't make sense I didn't find compelling, like the WOW signal that might be aliens. But overall the book is very much worth reading and explains some major scientific anomalies in a very understanding way.

This book discusses what might be the frontiers of science, except that some of the problems have been around a long time. The range from current dilemmas in astrophysics--the missing matter and dark energy to the cold fusion controversy and go on to explore if have already been contacted by aliens, the problem of understanding death and sex in basic biology and end with the placebo effect. Really well written and addressed to the layman the book is a fun read while making you think.

This book provides a "layman's overview" of some mysteries and anomalies in modern science - the phenomena that scientists still can't quite explain. These include such topics as "missing mass" in the universe (dark matter, dark energy), the effects of homeopathic medicines, the still uncertain evidence relating to cold fusion experiments, the meaning of death and of free will, etc. Some of these were more interesting and persuasive than others, but I enjoyed the analysis.

Very well written and entertaining. The 13 anomalies that the author chronicles are interesting and thought provoking. Each subject is moved through with obviously detailed research of the points for and against and insights into the importance of each. The chapters flow well from one subject to another, highlighting how they are connected to one another. The writing is scientifically detailed but also explained very well for the layman who may not have any prior knowledge of the content.

I'm not sure that the author has countered the orthodoxy of the current explanation of many of the the 13 supposed anomalies with good science or good logic despite his PhD. But as that melancholy Dane said so long ago "There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, than are dreamt of in your philosophy". Regardless, I always like a well written and well thought out essay that challenges what we think we know.

The title of the book says it all. The author reviewed and discussed a number of areas where science still hasn't progressed far enough to answer all the questions which remain open. Among the areas he discusses are cosmological conundrums, cold fusion possibilities, medical questions involving placebos and homeopathy, and several biological areas. It just goes to prove that the more we learn, the more unknowns we discover.

Although I have a few issues with the writing and general attitude of this book, most of the material it covers is interesting. I'll freely admit that it would have gotten another star if it had been harsher on homeopathy- such quackery warrants not so much as a second glance, and I was only able to tolerate that chapter with a steady flow of childish name-calling.More like NOmeopathy, am I right? More like homeAPATHY, am I right?

A fun, well written review of 13 current unansweared questions in modern science that spans from comology to biology. Assumes no previous knowledge of the topics in order to appreciate these quandries, and makes a pretty cogent argument that these unsolved questions are not dead ends but rather doors to the next advance in their respective areas. Includes just enough history of science to give you a background and to entertain you with the petty intrigues of "rational" scientists.

A fun and lively discussion of select items of scientific interest that have - as yet - escaped proper explanation. As with many books of this ilk, the reader can clearly see how the writer stared up at the cosmos as a child and wondered. I am numbered amongst that kind. What's interesting is that science wil eventually fill these gaps, and this book will be "12 things" then "9 things" until finally it will be obsolete. Enjoy the book before that happens.

Well written, thought provoking and educational. This asks more than it answers - like science generally. The first chapter is captivating and this probably will lead some readers to consider in depth unusual subjects that they might otherwise not. The choice of topics is well justified and together they broadly challenge how well we know things and how much (or little) we know. Perhaps one to look back on in 50 years to see how we're getting on.

I've been away from the state of the science for a while, and this book is an excellent catch up for anyone. Succinct, distilled, well-organised chapters proceed to reveal scale as well as the not-so topsy-turvy anomalies of the universe of dark matter all the way down to your homeopathic cures. Many things to discover in this book, and it is going to be fruitful for anyone to bootstrap where they left off the challenges of scientific discovery and explanation.

Rating: 4.25 out of 5This book is one of those which compels one to think and encourages one to learn more, to educate oneself. Being a nerd/geek that I am, the whole concept of these amazing yet baffling mysteries science faces today, attracted me and I wanted to read this as fast as possible. I practically lived with this book while I was reading it.To read more please do visit:http://untitledbyfelicia.blogspot.in

This book kept my interest all the way through and dove deep enough into the topic areas to give me an appreciation of the depth people of the problems that it presented.For Technical subject matter, I found Michael's writing style accessible, engaging, and easy to understand - made me want to dive further into some of the subject matter.Recommended for anyone with a scientific background who likes to get a broader sense of some of today's largest scientific enigma's are.

Intriguing that I read this book at the same time I was reconsidering re-reading Thomas Kuhn's The Structure of Scientific Revolution. The premise is different areas of science where we don't have robust enough theories to support possible contradictory evidentiary findings to current theories.Where do these items take science? Unclear, but lots of yummy food for thought. To quote Hamlet, "There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, than are dreamt of in your philosophy."

This book is something anyone who has an inkling of an interest in science should read. It grabs your attention from the beginning, and doesn't let go until the last bit. Even the epilogue keeps your attention! And it's little things tossed in like the phrase "sperm is cheap and plentiful" or referring to young bucks as "little fuckers" that keeps you laughing - totally unexpected from a scientific book.

Just listened through the audiobook.Chapters of various scientific study that flirt with fringe, but probably only because they are underfunded, politically hot, or generally unstudied. Makes my Skeptic sense tingle pretty much constantly. But it also seems legit and well researched. It was great. Like listening to a 4 hour episode of Radio Lab, without all the sound effects and goofy banter.The chapters on Life, Death and Free Will were standouts.

This is a fascinating book. I'm not sure that all the topics are about things that don't make sense - like the strong evidence that there is life on Mars - but each topic is fascinating. It is hard not to be fascinated by the fact that we don't actually know what life is, questions like why we die and why evolution has supported sexual reproduction or the evidence that we don't really have free will.A thought provoking book - highly recommended.

I would suggest that you feel you have at least a basic understanding of science before reading this book. It's not so technically written that the layperson cannot understand it, but the more exposure you've had to physics, chemistry, and biology,the more sense it's going to make to you. The "13 Things" pondered here include cold fusion, life, death, sex, free will, the placebo effect, and homeopathy, among others.

While not all of his arguments were sound, and he didn't look at all the possibilities (probably for time and length reasons) these 13 things that don't make sense were pretty cool. It was a well written and engaging book. It got me asking a lot of questions about life and science. And I think the biggest thing it did is instill a sense of wonder and excitement in me. The world around us is far less understood that scientists and schooling makes us believe.

I thought this was a good and entertaining book. However, I felt that the material could have worked better as a series of long articles instead of being collected in a book. Additionally, I do think it suffered a bit since it's publication (now 6 years ago). I know there had been scientific finds and breakthroughs which have made some parts of the book outdated. Nevertheless, I learned some things and thought it was a worthwhile read.

I didn't realize this book would have such a deep level of science facts in it. The 13 things are all cool and interesting to learn about, but be prepared to have your brain melted by scientific analysis about pretty complex scientific topics. Unless you're a physicist a good amount of this stuff may go in one ear and out the other. But enough sinks in that you can appreciate how complex the 13 things are and how much we've put into trying to figure them out.

Nerd alert. Lots of thought provoking concepts to ponder, and of course, it is very humbling to see how little we actually know. We don't know what life is, what death is, why it is necessary, why the placebo effect works and many other things. I am set for my next 10 or 15 dinner parties. This was a good book, that I would recommend to techies, science lovers, and polymaths. Reminiscent of Secrets of the Lost Races, a book I read back in high school.

Interesting stuff! Although sometimes it seems the writer is presenting findings and research which is either not peer reviewed or are rejected by the researchers themselves. So it kinda damages that "mystery" thing the writer is looking for. For example the chapter on Homoeopathy was filled with this kind of evidence presented in support of Homoeopathy and then all of them were later on rejected or found inconclusive. Homoeopathy is still not very mysterious. It's just pseudo-science!

Not all 13 things were a surprise but its nevertheless a good read. It sure does expose the underbelly of the scientific community when you realise that there are things shoved under the carpet and not everything so much in black and white and how you need to be networked and influential to be taken seriously even though you may have a killing radical discovery. The risk of being an outcast seems so real even in this community!

Overall a good book that explores things in science that a) don't make sense with our current theories or b) make sense, but are still under scrutiny from the science community. The one complaint I have is the author only explores a couple of topics (physics and biology) amongst the 13 chapters. A good read overall.

I tried listening to this. It was not what I expected - it was much drier. I found myself making nerd jokes while the narrator was talking about science in a frustratingly not-quite-witty way. The good thing about the talking book is they've split it up so each section is one chapter. I think I'd rather get this in print so I can skim and skip around the topics.

I really liked this book because it summed up my experience with science so well. Scientists are incredibly resistant to change, to the extent that they will go to great lengths to ignore, cover up, and deny evidence that might mean that they're wrong about something or that their theories need tweaking.

The library doesn't have this. It sounds interesting, if only to hear how a "New Scientist" journalist treats science's mysteries. I was surprised that some reviewers mocked the inclusion of homeopathy as a subject. Multiple universes are more interesting than the "energy" of a substance, in unmeasurably small quantities, that can heal without side effects!? That's amazing, in my book.

Hot and cold. Some of the chapters blew my brain. Others were stretches on the theme. I think i would have given this 5 stars if it was "6 things that don't make sense," however they would have had a hard time marketing a much shorter book. The Pioneer Anomaly chapter has to be my absolute favorite.

Like 13 Discover Magazine articles or Radiolab excerpts. (makes sense these are from the New Scientist) The 13 thing are listed here. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/13_Thin...Page 78. A nice analogy. Looking at a car does not tells us anything of traffic jams. More is Different. I am reading this as a book but feel this would be excellent as an audiobook.

Sometimes I like science books that arrange material in a curious manner, like different ways the Earth could end. Brooks mysteries are hit or miss. While some subjects I found to be of great interest like how come we can account for only 4 percent of the universe, and what is and how does the placebo effect work, while other mysteries aren't -cold fusion, homeopathy -hence two stars.

Building on Thomas S. Kuhn's classic, "The Structure of Scientific Revolutions," Brooks covers 13 current anomolies in science, demonstrating that no matter how much we think we know, there is always much we don't. So much so, that we are undoubtedly due for as many scientific revolutions in the future as we have had in the past. Very interesting reading.

A great book to wonder by. Michael Brooks does a great job in presenting the great scientific mysteries of our time. You will be surprised and be made to feel a bit uncomfortable with your understanding of reality. My favorite of the 13 things was the intelligent signal from space and section on free will.

borrowed to read a single chapter-on the mimivirus.shallow, not badly written, popular science.perhaps a bit more speculative than it should be.ok for light breezy reading through fields new to you-introduction.same genre as series of best science writing of 20xx.that i am reading through now.that series is much better.best skip it.

This book contains quite a lot of detail for being a series of short surveys. Brooks writing is not overly lively, but the subjects are engaging and he keeps the pace and the interest of the reader. It is great how he manages to tie the segments together, flowing natural from one conundrum to another.

I found this book very interesting once I got into it. For all of the certainty that science seems to take on a variety of issues, there are some mysteries that defy the so called laws. The topics covered range from astro physics observations that threaten Newton and Einstein theories to life, death, sex and even homeopathy! It was a worthwhile read.

An interesting topic, may be a bit deep for some. However, as much as this claims to be a science book, it amazes me how much of it is filled with theories, ideas, thoughts, wrong assessments, missed truths and wrong conclusions. I basically learned that very little science is absolute (at least as presented in this book). An interesting insight into the field of theory.

Another thought provoking sciencey book (after all, let's face it, science is just so darned sexy). 13 things looks at common events or phenomena that shouldn't work but do. It's written in a very accessible, chatty way. It covers a number of issues from physics, biology, the universe and beyound and is filled with asides and anecdotes. I very much enjoyed it.

A really good summary of some of the great mysteries left in science. I really enjoyed reading this. Particularly the sections on sex and death, biological mysteries. Not quite worth 5 stars due to the inclusion of the pseudoscience homeopathy in the last chapter - there is no mystery, it doesn't work!

This was very informative. It dispels many of the scientific urban legends (such as cold fusion) and helps the reader gain a better grasp of advanced scientific topics that are still not understood. Though it was not a riveting book I would recommend it to anyone who is curious about some of the most famous scientific mysteries.

Thought provoking for anyone who has questions about science and how the world works. Not anti-science, but a thoughtful exploration of how we come to so-called laws of science, and how much more we have to learn. Great stuff. This book of unanswered questions, makes science more interesting than any list of comfortable answers. Well written, acessible read.

Very interesting look into a range of things from what fills the universe, to sex, to medicine in a range of things that science not only can't explain, but which simply contradict some of our most basic and fundamental scientific rules about how the world works. Very enjoyable, well written and well researched.

The hardest barrier in this book is the pedantic language and scientific jargon...but at the core of it is a powerful message on understanding ourselves...and how fear, arrogance, politics, and erroneous beliefs about things keep us in the dark. I find that the same emotion to understand something is what drives both the scientist and the novelist.

As a skeptic who reads up a lot of weird things people believe and why, I found that a lot of the stuff in this book are things I've heard and read already. It's still an amazing book to read if you don't know much about free will, homeopathy, placebo, and etc. I would give it a 5 because if someone has never heard about these mysterious items, it'll be a treat to them to read.

Michael Brooks does the best job of putting all the known facts together is the best possible way. He never fails to give a thorough description while being extremely entertaining. He tackels subjects, like the emergence of life or the evolutionary purpose of death, just as many authors do, but he does not require that you be particularly good at science. He is simply fabulous.

The book started out as I expected it to, going over some really thought provoking stuff.But I felt that at times it would wonder a little bit. And it started to lose my attention toward the end, as the subject matter started to lean more on the medical side. Not a bad book, just not as captivating or interesting as what I have been reading lately

This book has some very interesting information. I also love the premise. It is not the "Aha!" moments that lead to the big breaks in science, it is the "Well that's odd..." ones. This book walks you though 13 of today's scientific oddities: cold fusion, free will, life, death, sex and more! Definitely a book worth reading!

If you like science you will enjoy this book. Well written and put forward many intriguing ideas and theories. The author Brooks is a scientist himself, who has turned to journalism. He does an excellent job of describing very complicated topics and making them understandable. He covers topics from Physics to Biology with lots and his topics make the busy a quick and easy read.

Sometimes the most interesting books give you more questions than answers. This book goes through some of the more baffling questions scientists and others are struggling with today. Some are contradictions to the scientific laws we've created, while others are more just curiosities. Definitely worth a read.

This is a very interesting book, but Brooks' writing is a little muddy, especially in the theoretical physics chapters. These are (obviously) very complex topics and I get the feeling that he has about as much of a grasp on the material as I do. The biology chapters were easier to focus on, but still not the best writing. The topics were interesting enough though to still enjoy the book.

I just skimmed this one. I didn't find his takes on the topics very interesting. Had a confusing feel when confronting controversy of either being really dogmatic or ambivalent. It seems to depend on which would stir up more feeling. The chapter on Cold Fusion was mildly entertaining.

Dark matter, dark energy, the Pioneer anomaly, the third Viking experiment, sex, death, life, cold fusion, constants of nature that aren't, homeopathy and the placebo effect. I think I'm missing one. This was an exciting book in that it poises us on the verge of new scientific discoveries.

Knowing that the smartest people on the planet are unsure of so many of the big things is liberating. I no longer need to be concerned that the only thing I know for sure is that I am hungry.I am going to read it again soon.

An acceptable popular science book. Better than some, worse than others. But a real easy, quick read. Dodges making any claims or decisions in favor of just presenting the evidence on both sides. Though you can tell it really knows what it wants you to think in most of the examples.

fascinating and superbly well written, with Witt and insight. Opens up your eyes to the gaping holes in our precious science and the tremendous possibilities opened up by that. diverse topics are tied neatly together.Favourite quote "Cold fusion is now as popular as pornography in church"

This book tackles some of the most interesting scientific debates going on right now. This book really makes you think. How do you define life? death? How about understanding the debacle around cold fusion or life on Mars. This is very readable and I enjoyed it immensely.

Quite interesting if you have any interest in science.However, don't bother to read chapters 11-13 which are nonsense, and not scientifically puzzling. At least not to real scientists.The epilogue is OK.

This is an excellent review of 13 thorny issues in various scientific disciplines. Also a subtle introduction into the philosophy of science. If you think that it is a subject where 'facts' are a matter of black and white certainty then you definitely need to read this.

I'm sure a few scientists would be annoyed that some of these chapters were included, but I think Brooks was very honest in describing the data objectively, neither credulous nor incredulous, just describing the dilemmas.
At times I felt like I would have enjoyed the book more if I had paid more attention in science class but over all it was very interesting.Its a good combination of light reading and heavy thoughts.

I will be honest, it is possible this book was just too "deep" for me. I was only interested in certain portions of it. The placebo part was probably the most interesting to me. I wouldn't recommend taking to the time to get through this book unless you are VERY interested in the subject.

I found this book extremely interesting, and very well written. The topics range from Cosmology (dark matter and dark energy) to the Placebo Effect and Homeopathy. All subjects that raise some interesting questions.Highly recommended!

The author looks at some scientific subjects that just don't seem to make sense--including a missing portion of the universe, cold fusion, life on Mars and extraterrestrial contacts, sex as a poor form of reproduction, free will, the placebo effect and the "science" of homeopathy. Good stuff!

I found this to be an interesting book that brought up several interesting anomalies, most of which I'd never heard of or at least found new aspects that I was previously unaware of.I would recommend this as a bit of light reading to anyone that was interested in science and discovery.

Wonderfully written, enjoyable read, very true to the known facts of science and the mysteries of science, explaining that the unknowns are every bit as important as the knowns in our quest for understanding.

Very fun read. It easily described currently unsolved problems in science and all implications that go along with them. It is fun to see all the directions people are exploring in several different realms. Quick read not to difficult.

The chapters on homeopathy and the 'inconstant constants' were both fascinating. Overall it was interesting and well written, but the frequent criticism of science (scientists, really) of being clique-ish and unwilling to accept new ideas - while maybe true - detracted from the topics a bit.

Okay book, some interesting perspectives on unanswered questions about our world. As one reviewer before said, the epilogue / ending was probably better to read first then the individual chapters. Overall, decent read and interesting discussion.

Interesting topics, and a good overview of each in my opinion. I was listening to the audio version, though, and my attention would often wander. Probably better as hard-copy, where the reader can go back and forth over the material to keep it all straight.

The book was OK but had to tie in together the 13 things that don't make sense were interested but each of the chapters were disjointed and their was no overall narrative to assist with joining the 13 things together.

Have now skimmed and dipped into this as much as I am going to. Very interesting. Approachable prose; a good argument about how scientific curiosity should function; cool scientific conundrums; a great intro./motivator for any budding scientists.

Interesting survey of the 13 or 14 things that are still major puzzles in science today. Good explanations for most, although some of the things and explanations get pretty technical.Nice to know we don't know a lot.

Great book, great info. I think it will humble those that think we know everything about science. It also shows what science should be, and where scientists fail. It is very pro-science and does not try to demean what we do know, just shows we don't know everything.

This book is more of a scientific book than a fiction fun read. It briefly discusses 13 things that don't make sense in science. These range from cold fusion to life and death. Interesting but it got boring at times.

Good review of across the sciences of current mysteries and contradictions. Slightly alarmist on the inability to describe the phenomena, but at the same time an entertaining read in understanding these limitations.

I stopped reading this book a few months ago and only just finished it today. So my rating probably means little. I didn't stop reading because it was boring, I just got distracted and forgot about it.

Mind=Blown!Great book, makes you think, and want to research and read more on these science mysteries. Contains some "science speak", but nothing too deep that you can't figure it out. Well written with credible sources. Really fascinating book!

It keeps an open mind about fringe science (and sadly, sometimes pseudo-science) - not critical enough of bad experiments and methods and does not elaborate when saying an experiment was flawed - But it's still a good read.

An excellent book that tells us which are 13 of the misters of the world that have scientist scratching their heads for an explanation. It reminds us of the methodic progress of science and how scientist own biases can also slow down the process of learning. A must read.

Brooks evokes some wonder as he surveys a group of questions raised largely in the area of cosmology and biology. It's uneven reading: some of the discussions are a bit pedestrian. Overall, though, some intriguing questions are raised and it's a perspective not often seen with some.

A good layman's summary of some of the things scientists are still trying to figure out. I was particularly interested in the chapter on Death, as Mark is now working with a professor on genetic engineering and Telomerase, which was mentioned in the chapter.

Kind of interesting topics, but to me it started in on the scientific version of Ayn Randian ramblings quite quickly. There's not enough evidence to even get close to a conclusion with any of the sections, but it seems they drag on forever. A fun concept, but super dry.

A little cooky and off the deep end sometimes (including wearing tinfoil hats). At the same time Brooks is self aware enough to be self critical. I am intrigued especially by the notion that now all substances act equally as a placebo.
